lesson.name: 5A - EI for Content Learning and the Use of Graphic Organizers to Define Learning

page.title: Review and Session 5 Objectives
page.contents:
Last session we:

  • Examined how to structure scaffolded practice as an important component of EI.
  • Explored the teacher’s role in guided, peer-assisted, and independent practice.
  • Described ways to provide lesson closure.


In this session we will:

  • Review key EI concepts.
  • Examine how EI can be used to teach content knowledge.
  • Explore how to map concepts for EI lesson planning using different types of graphic organizers.
  • Apply the explain and model parts of an EI lesson to content teaching.
  • Begin development of an EI lesson to introduce, explain and model content.
  • Refine your EI Lesson for a skill or strategy via facilitator and peer feedback.

Explicit Instruction Lesson Plan – Content Learning

We will again work through the four parts of an explicit instruction lesson. In this session we will focus on the first two parts:

  1. Lesson Introduction <<<<
  2. Teacher Explanation and Modeling <<<<
  3. Practice
  4. Closure


Click on the Next button below to continue.

page.title: EI Review – Skills and Strategy Learning
page.contents:
In the next two sessions, we are going to apply explicit instruction principles to teaching content. We’ll begin our discussion with a quick review of EI lesson design for skills and strategy learning.

In Session 1 we explored principles of explicit instruction. One principle is that learning is precisely defined.

In Sessions 2 – 4 we examined how we use this principle when we are teaching strategies and skills. As a reminder:

A basic skill is a procedure that with practice can be performed automatically. Basic skills require very little or no higher order thinking. The example skill we used earlier was adding decimals.

A strategy is a procedure a learner uses to perform a complex task. Strategies are comprised of thinking and action steps to help learners develop higher order thinking skills. The example strategy we used earlier was QAR – a tool for teaching learners how to answer literal and inferential reading comprehension questions.

We precisely define skills and strategies by doing a task analysis.
A task analysis is the process of breaking down an academic task into a procedure that teachers can explain and demonstrate.

Here are the two example task analyses we’ve used in the course so far:

Skill Example

Strategy Example

QAR – Question, Answer, Response

Right There – Identify information that is in one place in the passage.

Think and Search – Identify information that has to be put together from different parts of the passage.

Writer and Me – Identify how what you already know helps you understand the reading.

Now let’s take a look at content learning and how it differs from skill and strategy learning.

Click Next below to continue

page.title: EI Content Learning
page.contents:
What is Content Learning?

Content learning is focused on acquiring new vocabulary and concepts. This type of learning is a little different from skills and strategy learning.  Skills and strategy learning is procedural in nature, while content learning is declarative.

Procedural vs. Declarative Knowledge

Procedural knowledge addresses knowing how to do something.
Skills and strategy learning is focused on developing learners’ procedural knowledge. For example, knowing how to:

  • get from one city to another,
  • find the main idea in a paragraph, or
  • decode words that have multiple syllables.


Declarative knowledge is knowing about something. Content learning is focused on developing learners’ declarative knowledge. For example, knowing:

  • that Washington, DC is the capital of the U.S.,
  • why 90 degrees is a hot day, or
  • the differences between socialism and capitalism.


Both types of knowledge are important for school learning. Both types of knowledge can be developed with explicit instruction.

Given this difference, how do you think EI lessons for content learning will differ from EI lessons for skill and strategy learning?  What might change? Would you use different techniques for one or more of the four EI lesson steps? Would the lesson format itself differ?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Content Learning – Lesson Format
page.contents:
For content learning, the EI lesson format itself does not change. All the elements on the Lesson Plan outline linked below still apply: 

EI Lesson Plan Outline

In fact, all elements of the lesson introduction step remain exactly the same for content learning:

  • gaining students’ attention
  • informing students of the session’s objective/s
  • identifying reason/s to learn
  • connecting to prior knowledge
  • reviewing & checking for prerequisite skills
  • preteaching vocabulary

The explanation and modeling step, however, looks significantly different. As we just reviewed, we use task analysis to precisely define the procedures for skills and strategy learning. For content learning we need a different process to break down the information for learners.

For content learning the goal of the explain and model step is to: (a) identify key vocabulary and concepts students need to understand and then (b) organize information in a way to promote learner comprehension and retention.

Graphic organizers can be one of the most effective tools to precisely define content.


Have you used graphic organizers with adult learners? What graphic organizers have you used and for what purpose? Do you feel they are effective? Why?

 Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Content Learning – Why Graphic Organizers #1
page.contents:
How can graphic organizers be an effective tool in explicit instruction?

Graphic organizers can help the teacher to identify the most important information students need to learn.

The amount of possible content to be taught can be overwhelming for both teachers and students. The structure of graphic organizers force decisions about what content is critical.

Here is an example of a graphic organizer developed by a teacher after analyzing a chapter on climates that students will be reading. This graphic organizer helped the teacher identify the key concepts presented in the chapter and the relationships between the concepts.

Source:  Cited as TATC on page 116 of: Taymans, J. M. (2010). Learning to Achieve:
A professional’s guide to educating adults with learning disabilities.
National Institute for Literacy, Washington, D.C.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Content Learning – Why Graphic Organizers #2
page.contents:
How can graphic organizers be an effective tool in explicit instruction?

Graphic organizers can provide a visual representation of information, organized into a structure that helps students to see relationships between concepts.
This can help students make connections with what they already know (their prior knowledge). It can also help students make connections between key concepts and vocabulary words that are new to them.


The graphic organizer below would be one way to help learners connect the vocabulary word leisure to what they already know by helping them identify their leisure activities.


Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Content Learning – Why Graphic Organizers #3
page.contents:
How can graphic organizers be an effective tool in explicit instruction?

#3) Graphic organizers provide a structure for learners who have difficulty organizing information or who need concrete representations to structure ideas.

Note that while the text-based graphic organizer on the left below is accurate and helpful, the pictures on the other graphic organizer below provides a more concrete representation of each of the three branches of government.

 

 




How do these reasons for using graphic organizers compare with your earlier reflections on graphic organizers?  Have you used a graphic organizer with your adult learners for any of these purposes? Are the graphic organizers you’ve used similar to any of the examples?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Planning EI for Content Learning
page.contents:
In EI for content learning, a teacher would use a graphic organizer to explain content and demonstrate how to use the graphic organizer to deepen learners’ knowledge.  Learners would then practice using the graphic organizer to further explore the content, or to explore related content.

Let’s look at how to integrate graphic organizers into an EI lesson. The first step would be to prepare for teacher Explanation and Modeling.

In content learning, the teacher identifies key concepts and/or vocabulary and organizes the information so that learners can explore the content in a way that will aid comprehension and retention.

The first challenge for teachers, then, is to determine what types of organization and relationship connections will be most beneficial to student comprehension and retention. Graphic organizers come in many different shapes and sizes - what type of graphic organizer would be best for the content?  

Let’s examine some possible ways of organizing information using graphic organizers.
 
Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Organizing Content for EI – Hierarchical Concepts #1
page.contents:
Concept Maps

Concept maps show hierarchical relationships, with the most important (or overarching) concept placed at the top and supporting concepts below.

Below are examples of concept maps you've already seen with the central concept at the top of the map:

 

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Organizing Content for EI – Hierarchical concepts #2
page.contents:
Spider Concept Map

More complex or more elaborated concepts can be structured with the main concept in the center and supporting concepts and details surrounding the central concept. These are sometimes called spider concept maps.  


Below are examples of a more complex concept maps with the central concept at the center of the map:
 

*Created by learners in Fife, Scotland, using mapping software. Used with permission of James Birney.
  

Click the Next button below to continue.

page.title: Organizing Content for EI – Compare/Contrast
page.contents:
Venn Diagram

A compare/contrast or Venn diagram provides a structure for identifying similarities and differences between two or more concepts.
    

Below is an example of a Venn diagram comparing two concepts:

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Organizing Content for EI – Sequence
page.contents:
Sequence Graphic Organizers

Any concept that has a distinct order can be presented in a sequence chart. For example, this graphic organizer can be used to outline key events in a story or in history.


 

Below is an example of a sequence graphic organizer – the steps for how a bill becomes law in the U.S.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Organizing Content for EI – Cause and Effect
page.contents:
Cause and Effect Diagrams

 This graphic organizer shows the direct relationship between different events or concepts. This can be used in any subject area for tasks such as:

  • analyzing characters and events in a story

  • mapping historical events in social studies

  • identifying outcomes of variables in an experiment

 

Try filling out the cause-effect graphic organizer linked below with the information provided. (You will be able to print your completed form, but you may not be able to save it.)

Simple Cause-Effect Form

Causes and Effects of Water Pollution:

There are two main causes of water pollution. One is the  dumping of industrial waste into rivers, streams, and oceans, and the other is insecticides/pesticides from agribusiness farming leaching into ground water. Two major effects of water pollution are (1) fish, birds and animals die from exposure to chemicals and (2) people become sick or diseased from direct contact with water, such as diarrhea, or from eating creatures exposed to polluted water.

For your classroom use, here is a blank version of the cause and effect graphic organizer: Cause & Effect Graphic Organizer

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Organizing Content for EI – Graphic Organizers for Vocabulary
page.contents:
A major facet of content learning is acquiring important vocabulary. There are many types of graphic organizers designed to help learners comprehend and use new vocabulary.

Some titles of vocabulary graphic organizers include: word maps, word charts, verbal and visual word associations, and the Frayer Word Model. Let's look at two examples of Vocabulary graphic organizers

Below is a simple graphic organizer designed to assist students to self-assess their knowledge of new vocabulary. A final empty column can be added for the learner to fill in with their own definitions from readings and/or class discussions.

Blachowicz & Fisher, 2006

Our second example of a vocabulary graphic organizer is one learners can use to study individual vocabulary terms.


Eeds & Cockrum, 1985


Have you used vocabulary graphic organizers like these with your adult learners?  If not, how do you assist them to learn new vocabulary?

 

Click on the Next button below to continue.

page.title: Organizing Content for EI – Vocabulary: Frayer Model
page.contents:
Like the previous graphic organizer, the Frayer Model of vocabulary learning also provides a table with 4 cells learners use to make multiple connections to new words. In this case, the four cells are headed: Definition, Characteristics, Examples and Non-examples.

 

Here is an example of a Frayer graphic organizer used in a science context for the word crystal.



Try filling out a blank Frayer graphic organizer linked below with a vocabulary word of your choice.
(You will be able to print your completed form, but you may not be able to save it.)

Frayer Model form  pdf FORM

For your own classroom use, here is a blank Fryer Model:  Frayer Model (pdf format)

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Building Your Knowledge of Graphic Organizers
page.contents:
These are just a few of the most common graphic organizers available to teachers and students for organizing content. There are many, many more. Luckily, there are many easily accessible repositories of graphic organizers for educators available on the web.

Earlier we noted that:

The first step in planning an EI lesson for content learning is to determine what types of organization and relationship connections will be most beneficial to student comprehension and retention.

In order to make these decisions effectively, instructors need to be familiar with a wide range of graphic organizers. (Even more than we’ve shown you here!)

To assist you in making these decisions, we ask you to take some time to explore one or more web-based collections of graphic organizers before moving on to the next session.

Use the links on the first page of the Session 5 References and Resources document linked below to explore online various graphic organizers and their purposes.  Make note of the web addresses for  3-5 specific graphic organizers* that are both new to you and that you feel would be useful for your learners.  You will share these with your peers in the following forum discussion post.

Explicit Instruction Session 5 Resources and References
*Be sure to share the web address from the specific page for the graphic organizer 
– not the whole collection site!

Note: This activity will also assist you in completion of the Assignment for this session.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Summary: EI for Content Learning & Using Graphic Organizers to Define Learning
page.contents:
In this lesson we examined a process for identifying, organizing and clarifying declarative knowledge as part of an EI lesson through the use of graphic organizers.

Like the task analysis, the graphic organizer and its use in organizing the content forms the basis for the Explain and Model steps of the EI Lesson. Also like the task analysis, the graphic organizer can also help to inform the prerequisite component of the Lesson Introduction, and is thus a critical step in planning an EI lesson for content learning.

What are your thoughts regarding the use of graphic organizers to support content learning? What benefits do you see in these tools? What questions or concerns do you have?

You will be asked next to share these reflections, as well as the graphic organizers you chose from the web exploration activity in a post to a Discussion forum. Once you have completed your post, we will move on to examine how to conduct the Explain and Model component of an EI Lesson for content learning using a graphic organizer.

Click Next to end this lesson, return to the Main Course Menu, and access the next session section.
